issue.title: Add denote test #11495
issue.body:
<!--
Thanks for submitting a PR, your contribution is really appreciated!

Here is a quick checklist that should be present in PRs.

- [ ] Include documentation when adding new features.
- [ ] Include new tests or update existing tests when applicable.
- [X] Allow maintainers to push and squash when merging my commits. Please uncheck this if you prefer to squash the commits yourself.

If this change fixes an issue, please:

- [ ] Add text like ``closes #XYZW`` to the PR description and/or commits (where ``XYZW`` is the issue number). See the [github docs](https://help.github.com/en/github/managing-your-work-on-github/linking-a-pull-request-to-an-issue#linking-a-pull-request-to-an-issue-using-a-keyword) for more information.

Unless your change is trivial or a small documentation fix (e.g., a typo or reword of a small section) please:

- [ ] Create a new changelog file in the `changelog` folder, with a name like `<ISSUE NUMBER>.<TYPE>.rst`. See [changelog/README.rst](https://github.com/pytest-dev/pytest/blob/main/changelog/README.rst) for details.

  Write sentences in the **past or present tense**, examples:

  * *Improved verbose diff output with sequences.*
  * *Terminal summary statistics now use multiple colors.*

  Also make sure to end the sentence with a `.`.

- [ ] Add yourself to `AUTHORS` in alphabetical order.
-->
Add denotation, users now can use annotation to denote a test:
@pytest.mark.test
def hello():
assert 5 == 5

test case could be found in testing/test_denotation.py
the relative issue url is: https://github.com/pytest-dev/pytest/issues/11495

comment.body:
Other than the above, we also need buy-in from other maintainers, given this is an important new feature.

cc @The-Compiler @bluetech @RonnyPfannschmidt @Pierre-Sassoulas @asottile

review.body:
We need first decide how we want to mark tests.

I like the idea, I also think being able to mark tests explicitly and use short names is a good one, similar to how it is done in Rust.

I would prefer a `@pytest.test` decorator rather than a mark: a test is certainly a first class citizen, as fixtures are, so we should use `@pytest.test` directly.

The implementation for the decorator should be trivial: it can just add a `__pytest_test__` attribute to the function, and we can then check for this attribute during collection to identify test functions.

One downside is that there would be now two ways to declare a test, using the decorator or the traditional prefix, but I don't see this as a major problem.

We will also need to update the docs accordingly, showing the new-style, the rationale, and that the traditional style of using a `test_` prefix is never going anywhere.

review.body:
We need first decide how we want to mark tests.

I like the idea, I also think being able to mark tests explicitly and use short names is a good one, similar to how it is done in Rust.

I would prefer a `@pytest.test` decorator rather than a mark: a test is certainly a first class citizen, as fixtures are, so we should use `@pytest.test` directly.

The implementation for the decorator should be trivial: it can just add a `__pytest_test__` attribute to the function, and we can then check for this attribute during collection to identify test functions.

One downside is that there would be now two ways to declare a test, using the decorator or the traditional prefix, but I don't see this as a major problem.

We will also need to update the docs accordingly, showing the new-style, the rationale, and that the traditional style of using a `test_` prefix is never going anywhere.

---

Other than that, we also need buy-in from other maintainers, given this is an important new feature.

cc @The-Compiler @bluetech @RonnyPfannschmidt @Pierre-Sassoulas @asottile

issue.title: Mention -q and -s in the docs
issue.body:
- Closes #11507.
- Added references to command line options `-q (--quiet )` ,`--capture` and `-s (--capture)` in the output documentation.

comment.body:
Seems like some incompatibility in Python 3.12 while building the package, unrelated to your changes.

I will take a look ASAP.

issue.title: Doc fix issue #11556
issue.body:
- Closes #11556.
- Removed recommendation about using nullcontext + parametrize in the documentation.

comment.body: I'm OK with improving that section with some examples and alternatives, rather than just deleting it.

issue.title: Mention -q and -s in the docs
issue.body:
- Closes #11507.
- Added references to command line options `-q (--quiet )` ,`--capture` and `-s (--capture)` in the output documentation.

comment.body: @nicoddemus. I am sorry to bother, but I have no idea why the checks keep failing. Could you maybe help me ?

issue.title: Doc fix issue #11556
issue.body:
- Closes #11556.
- Removed recommendation about using nullcontext + parametrize in the documentation.

comment.body: I agree with @kalekundert, that it's nice to know it's possible to use context manager this way. It's probably more intuitive to do two tests functions one for each behavior I certainly did that a lot in the past without reading a doc to give me the idea, I also named fixture a particular way ``if "boom" in fixture_name`` to handle both use case in the same function. I think it's a neat idea about how to possibly design tests that one can follow -- or not. It's not linked to the pytest framework though, as it could be used with unittest's ``self.assertRaises`` instead of ``pytest.raises`` and a list of context manager instead of ``parametrize``. So maybe it's more suited to a blog post about unit test design than the pytest's doc ?

issue.title: Doc fix issue #11556
issue.body:
- Closes #11556.
- Removed recommendation about using nullcontext + parametrize in the documentation.

comment.body:
I know I'm not a big contributor to pytest, but for what it's worth, I don't agree with this change.  Real-world parametrized tests often have a lot of setup and teardown code, and writing separate test functions for the "should raise" and "shouldn't raise" cases is hard to do without duplicating this code.  I wrote about this a bit more extensively [here](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/67552586/pytest-mixing-exception-testing-using-pytest-mark-parametrize/67562035#67562035).

IMO, the documentation example could be improved by adding a way to specify an expected value in the case that no exception is raised, similar to what I show in the link above.  But removing the example altogether is a step in the wrong direction.

comment.diff_hunk:
@@ -36,6 +42,13 @@ option you make sure a trace is shown.
 Verbosity
 --------------------------------------------------
 
+Examples for modifying printing verbosity:
+
+.. code-block:: bash
+
+    pytest --quiet          # quiet - less verbose - mode
+    pytest -q               # quiet - less verbose - mode (shortcut)
+
 The ``-v`` flag controls the verbosity of pytest output in various aspects: test session progress, assertion
comment.body: Will do. I'm sorry I just try to not add anything I wasn't told

- Closes #11507.
- Added references to command line options `-q (--quiet )` ,`--capture` and `-s (--capture)` in the output documentation.

comment.diff_hunk:
@@ -36,6 +42,13 @@ option you make sure a trace is shown.
 Verbosity
 --------------------------------------------------
 
+Examples for modifying printing verbosity:
+
+.. code-block:: bash
+
+    pytest --quiet          # quiet - less verbose - mode
+    pytest -q               # quiet - less verbose - mode (shortcut)

comment.body:
It is a bit strange to list `-q` and `--quiet`, and right in the following paragraph discuss `-v`, which is not shown as example.

Please include `-v`, `-vv` and `-vvv` in the list above here as well.
